question: Why do you want to join the Tech Club?
What can you add to the team? (e.g., skills, ideas, or enthusiasm)
What do you enjoy the most about technology (games, apps, gadgets, coding, etc.) & what are your expectations about the future of technology?
Write about any project, competition, or tech-related activity you have done. (It can be small, like making a poster, fixing something, or trying an app/tool.)
What is one new skill you really want to learn this year and why?
Name one technology people talk about a lot. Do you think it’s useful or overhyped? Why?
Explain any tech thing you know in simple words (like Wi-Fi, app, robot, AI, etc.) so even a teacher who doesn’t know tech can understand.
Think of one idea using technology that can help our school (e.g., save electricity, reduce waste, make learning fun). Write it briefly.
Imagine you have one week for a small tech project. What are the first steps you’d take to get it ready, and then how would you actually do the work? Write the complete plan in brief.
What does ‘innovation’ mean to you? Share a small example (can be from school, home, or daily life).
How would you handle a situation where a teammate isn’t doing their part of the work?
How do you manage your time between academics, tech projects, health, and other activities?
Write 3 things you would put on a Tech Club website/app.
What is the best way to learn something new in technology?
options: Read about it for weeks first.
Try to make a small project quickly.
Teach it to a friend.
Wait until you feel 100% ready.

question: How do we know if a school tech project is successful?
options: It looks very fancy.
Students actually use it more than once.
It has many lines of code.
It solves one clear problem.

question: When you hear about a new technology, what should you do?
options: Believe it’s useful because experts say so.
Think about possible problems it may cause.
Think how it can help in simple ways at school.
Use it immediately to look modern.

question: What is most important when making something for students?
options: It looks cool to you.
Easy to use and clear.
First-time users can understand it quickly.
Add as many features as possible.

question: What makes a project useful beyond our school?
options: It solves a problem many people also face.
It needs special things only our school has.
Others can copy or repeat it easily.
Only one student knows how it works.

question: Commitment: Hours per week you can give to club activities.
options: 1-2 hours
2-4 hours
4-6 hours
6+ hours
